review_title: Some good changes but very concerned about the future
job_title: Anonymous in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros:
—Senior leadership is finally bringing ECRI into the 21st century with its aggressive business strategy and focus on technology
—Finally knocking the old building down and putting up a new one
—100% remote work allowed (even after the new building is ready) but not required
—Lots of good, smart people to work with
cons:
—Moving toward becoming a matrixed organization, which creates all sorts of confusion and inefficiencies
—General lack of transparency from senior leadership
—Senior leadership's aggressive business strategy has alienated many long-time employees who have made ECRI what it is
—Many long-time senior-level employees have already jumped ship or been forced out
—Bloated C-Suite with additional highly paid but ineffectual C-level positions being created, it seems, every quarter

review_title: Lots of change. Some good, some... well, not so good.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: The new regime (i.e., CEO, CFO, CMO, CTO, CLO, and other high-level personnel) has almost entirely replaced the previous rut-bound leadership and brought fresh, new ideas and vision to the organization. They are forward-looking and progressive in their outlook, strategy, and methods. Their focus on technology is wise and timely.
cons: There has been too much change too fast. The company has grown by something like 100 people over the past year, and many long-time employees (including a number of highly productive, intelligent, relatively high-level employees) have left ECRI Institute or have been nicely (or not so nicely) forced out. There is a lot of change, but even more upheaval and chaos. And some necessary things have been let go. For example, some of the bathrooms are only cleaned every few weeks, making for a rather disgusting environment, at least for employees who value cleanliness. There have been grandiose promises of a revitalization and renovation of work-spaces, but the latest word is that it might not happen. The culture has largely shifted from one of collegiality and trust to territoriality and cynicism.

job_title: Associate Director in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Ultimate Work from home
Mission driven organization
cons: Workplace as family and friends substitute

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Flexible work schedule, family oriented, casual environment, good pay and excellent benefits, senior management actually cares about the well being of their employees.  ECRI likes to hire from within and the average employee has been with the organization  5+ years.  ECRI truly believes in their mission "ECRI Institute is an independent nonprofit organization whose mission is to benefit patient care by promoting the highest standards of safety, quality, and cost-effectiveness in healthcare."  I was very proud to be an an employee of ECRI Institute for 9 years.
cons: The lack of communication between departments can often be frustrating.  Sales teams need to work together when supporting customers.  IT drives the bus and has way too much control regarding product development and enhancements.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros:
Worthy organizational mission
Dedicated and bright professional staff on the front lines for the most part
Some good managers
Decent benefits
Flex time for many departments
cons: Executive staff have been there too long--for some it's the only place they've ever worked--are inbred, do not mentor up and coming potential stars, do not invest in professional development or tuition reimbursement, and behavior suggests concern only about their respective groups, despite giving lip service to fostering collaboration among groups and viewing the organization as a whole, organic body. CEO is a joke. Lacks vision for the organization and leadership. Some have even said he is "losing it."  Sadly, "emperor with no clothes" has been uttered in the halls by more than a few who apparently know his M.O.  It's too bad, because the professional staff who actually do the work are highly conscientious and believe in the mission.  That said, career opportunities are somewhat limited because they don't invest in people's development.  Too bad the Board of Trustees of this nonprofit doesn't get what's going on.

review_title: Committed and really smart staff, great projects, and growing pains from rapid growth
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Exciting growth from small to medium company brought necessary changes, which have been many the past 2 -3 years with addition of 75 or more staff. Diverse projects, renewed emphasis on professional development and training opportunities and business line development offer new and interesting opportunities. Most staff are super smart and hail from diverse backgrounds--clinical, patient safety, health policy, research, medical communications--which makes work interesting. Nice blend of old-timers with fascinating experience and stories, and new folks with new energy. Large proportion of staff have been here 5 or more years--seem to be committed to the mission and want to make a difference in healthcare delivery here and around the world. Somewhat flexible work schedule environment. Family friendly. Open environment. Employee co-op sponsored events for socializing.
cons:
Physical space limits, tightening of some informal policies from yesteryear, and thin staffing because of new projects add stress.
Thin staffing prevents time for drumming up new ideas, considering them, and developing them

review_title: A place where taking time to read, research, think and write is the priority and not an afterthought to your "day job."
job_title: Analyst in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Quiet, peaceful work setting; high ethical standards; many highly intelligent individuals from varied backgrounds that act like true colleagues; focus on wellness for employees; the employee co-op plans many fun activities throughout the year to promote interaction between departments and build team pride.
cons: Perhaps too quiet for professionals that crave intensity (such as clinicians leaving the hospital environment to come to ECRI; the company has grown exponentially in recent years -long-term employees say ECRI has lost the small company feeling where everyone knew everyone else; many people that do not interact outside their own department; sedentary desk work - it is easy to gain weight if you don't make an effort to get up from your desk and move.

job_title: in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Great mission, well-respected name in the industry.  There are a lot of resources available for employees to make use of for projects.  A number of highly knowledgeable staff members are also great resources and well-respected in the healthcare community
cons: Zero upward mobility, unless someone quits or leaves.  The company is a big fan of giving titles and money to "squeaky wheel" staff to keep them.  Non-profit mentality pervades everything, from marketing plans to salary increases, and an "it's always been done this way" air is changing, but very slowly.  Very few staff and management have actually worked in hospitals (most have either research backgrounds or spent their entire time at ECR Institute) , which is a problem when the data doesn't match real world patient care.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: This institute was founded by a passionate physician who wanted to bring quality and safety to healthcare industry.
cons: Since the founder was made to step down in year 2000, a few con men took over and changed the direction and mission of this institute which used to be ensuring safety, quality, and effectiveness in healthcare. This institute was supposed to be run as a non-profit institute, however, under the new management (after year 2000), this institute has been converted to a for-profit institute to benefit the CEO, COO and the executive members.  They got rid of all the experts who worked for this institute for so many years, brought bunch of kids fresh out of school with very low salaries to reduce the cost of operation and maximize their benefit. As a result, the quality of the ECRI's services have been drastically  reduced and its reputation has been compromised.

review_title: Not a great place for information technology\software professionals
job_title: Systems Engineer in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Good place to work if you are not in Information Technology.
cons:
Poor IT leadership and inexperienced managers.
Lot of politics at management level.
Developers are used as tools to implement wrong ideas that managers think are cool. When these ideas are proved wrong, they axe falls on the developer and not the manager.
There are no testers. Developers have to test and be responsible to themselves and everybody in the team.
Managers work in silo and they expect developers to communicate at all the time.
Almost all the releases are late by the same duration they were originally planned.
If you are experienced developer there are no chances for promotion.
They claim to use latest technology, but you still have to work with .NET framework supported by their SharePoint installation in the latest version of Visual Studio.

review_title: Great mission, but poor management and high turnover
job_title: in Plymouth Meeting, PA

cons: Pay is at least 20% below industry standard. Management has very poor communication skills and often changes are made on a daily, if not hourly basis. This makes it very hard for employees to know what is "in" for the day. Confusing directions with little encouragement from supervisors. Some managers are not parents and don't understand that kids don't follow a set schedule all of the time.

review_title: Mission and much of the work good - culture, quite strange
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: The mission is an important one, and I think most people working at ECRI care about it and are highly motivated by it. There's a lot of very smart and hard-working people at ECRI, including some world-class experts in certain areas, and lots of others who are bringing their valuable clinical or technical or other professional experience into the policy world and trying very hard to make a change in the world of patient safety.  Also, on the "pro" side, the org. is - at least for me, as I have worked in a lot of corporate environments - not a terribly rigid or high pressure place to work; there are plenty of deadlines,  but at the same time most of my co-workers and my manager are reasonable people who want to work together collegially and there is not a sense that your head is on the chopping block if you legitimately can't make a particular deadline.  People help each other, people want to get the job done, managers help you juggle and prioritize. There is not a lot of corporate-style politics or drama, at least in my department. On the other hand, that may be a "con" as well, as there are some areas of the organization that are simply not particularly productive, and I am suspecting that under the new CEO, there may be more stress for some people than they're used to.  Other pros: flexible work hours; pretty campus, though isolated; casual dress; work from home option in some circumstances. Managers generally pretty reasonable about accommodating personal situations in terms of work/life balance.
cons: Okay, the cons. The culture at ECRI is VERY strange, and for me it was an enormous adjustment. I've worked a lot of places, but never anywhere as odd as this place. As a couple of other reviewers have said, there are a lot of smart but eccentric people here, and in some cases, that's putting it kindly.  My department was, until quite recently, SILENT, and some people are still simply rude and cold. Some attribute it to lack of social skills, I really still can't quite fathom it. There are a few people who behave downright bizarrely. Often they are long-timers or in some cases very young people who have never worked anywhere else and apparently don't realize their behavior would not cut it most places. I really don't know what explains this; I think it's just that ECRI is a unique organization and has grown into what it is organically - always going its own way because it has no other real "peers" who do exactly the same work. Certain things that management apparently does not see are simply crazy, are deep rooted.  FWIW, it took me a VERY long time to feel comfortable here. I do, finally, and feel that I have friends as well as a sense of belonging in the structure and contributing positively to worthwhile work. But it sure wasn't easy.  Other cons: All cubicles - really, ALL - gray walls, not a lot of natural light, bunkerish feel to the building - quite frankly, a bit prison-like. (The windows are prison-style slits.) No way to get there by public transportation, nowhere to walk to for lunch or anything else - there's a catering service that supplies lunches but they're not very varied. I personally hate the corporate-office-park setting even though there's a large green lawn, and next door is a cemetery where you can walk if you want. To summarize the main "cons": weirdest place I ever worked. ECRI does things how ECRI does them, and the newcomer will just have to get used to it. Of course, now we have a new CEO and he may turn the place upside down and shake out the people who can't adjust. I will not be surprised if there are major upheavals. Oh, and the pay stinks.

review_title: Good place to work at if you're not in IT
job_title: Systems Engineer in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros:

And they want to know why there's so much turnover in IT. Anyone could tell you if lthey werent so afraid.  But there is a lot of fear because everyone has seen what happens.

review_title: Poor management, unsustainable business model, refusal to keep up with times
job_title: in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Great mission, diverse work, good flexibility (work from home, on the road), open cubicles and laid-back culture; free coffee and soda, often free food in cafeteria
cons:
some management is resistant to change and keeping up with changing times (poor website cited as major obstacle to subscribing from clients for years and still has not been updated); culture is sometimes too laid back; hard to get things done; pay is below industry standard and raises are minimal

senior execs favors business units that are the big winners, when you have no control over this due to the business models set up; upward mobility is slim to none, based on time there instead of performance

oh - and the place feels depressing, the colors are all dull and dark, and there's no windows on the first floor

review_title: I produced delight for my customer(s), and fulfilling results for myself through this challenging opportunity.
job_title: Regional Account Executive in Chicago, IL
pros: Helping my customer to buy better / smarter figuratively moved me from sitting on the opposite side of the desk from my customer to be sitting right beside my customer.  It is a great feeling when my customer wins, my company wins, and I win, too.
cons: The sales management team which evolved to be in place during the middle portion of my tenure is small-minded and very politically striated; that culture manifests itself into interesting decisions and direction.

review_title: Run, don't walk, away from this company!
job_title: Technology Assessment in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros:
Work-from-home policies are nice; but they force you to work even if the office is closed for bad weather (i.e., no paid snow days, even during a blizzard). 
Free soda if you're into that sort of thing. 
The only good thing about the office are the high cubical walls -- you can easily listen to music or watch Netflix while working.
cons:
The executive staff have all been here way too long and they don't know how the real world works anymore. Executive staff act like they want all of the groups to work collaboratively, but I have only ever worked with my own group on our one sole project. You often see people in the hallways that you have never seen before and there is a high turn-over rate in certain departments. 
Pay is on the lower end and promotions almost never happen (unless you're at the top of your pay scale and they want to keep you with the company). No room for growth; the only time you'll work on a different project is if you move groups. Benefits are almost non-existent -- no tuition reimbursement, no maternity leave, very strict vacation and sick time policies. 
There is next to no professional development; I had to go out and pay for my own development courses. 
The building is like working in a basement; the only windows on the third floor are in the conference rooms. No fresh air, the cleaning staff is non-existent as there is dust covering everything -- the filing cabinets, the tops of cubicles. I have staples on my floor that have been there since I started so it's clear they never vacuum.

review_title: Good people to work with, some work balance issues

job_title: Senior Associate in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: The company is well intended as it's main focus is improving patient care. Most staff members are very bright and hard working individuals. The ability to learn new skills while working at ECRI is a plus as well.
cons: The managment structure, if you can call it a structure, is flawed in a multitude of ways.  There are no clear lines of communication, policies and procedures are applied in an extremely inconsistent fashion, and the amount of work expected of individuals in consulting roles is completely absurd.  Lastly, many in management roles were promoted for their technical acumen, but have absolutely no concept of what is needed to effectively motivate and manage their employees.
